Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Hierarchical Topic Modeling by Nonnegative Matrix Factorization for Interactive Multi-scale Analysis of Text Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
EAGER: Hierarchical Topic Modeling by Nonnegative Matrix Factorization for Interactive Multi-scale Analysis of Text Data

Nonnegative matrix factorization (NMF) has proven to be an important tool of choice for numerous data analytic problems in text, imaging, and computer vision. It provides advanced mathematical methods for improvements in dimensionality reduction, clustering, etc. A distinguishing feature of the NMF is the requirement of non-negativity in the factors that represent the matrix in a lower rank. This property greatly enhances the interpretability and modeling capability for many applications, where preserving non-negativity is important. This project is studying foundational properties of the NMF, producing new algorithmic methods using the framework of NMF for efficient and effective hierarchical clustering and topic modeling of large scale text data for multi-scale analysis, generating labels for the topics, and interactive analysis. In addition, an interactive visual analytic system for the proposed methods is being developed to make these theoretical and algorithmic discoveries readily available to the research and applications communities. New multi-scale hierarchical methods for generating clusters and discovering topics in the documents and detection of topic changes over time are being explored to enable computationally efficient and perceptually effective ways of exploring text data and discovering latent group structure. Visual analytic systems are also being developed based on this foundational work to enable more effective and informed discovery of topics in a large-scale document collection.

This project will have a significant impact on the analysis and development of NMF algorithms and new modeling of problems for applications utilizing the NMF (e.g., 'Big Data'). The project is yielding effective computational methods with solid analysis that will enhance the analysis of high-dimensional data in broad areas of science, engineering, medicine, and business disciplines beyond the application areas being considered within this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many problems in data analytics involve text and document data sets such as research papers, news articles, Wikipedia or social media like Twitter. In this project, an automated method is developed for discovering the topics covered in a text data set along with the top keywords representing each topic and the proportion of topics represented in each text. In addition, a very fast and accurate method called HierNMF2, which computes a hierarchical topics based a constrained low rank approximation called NMF (Nonnegative Matrix Factorization) was designed. An open source software called SmallK (smallk.github.io) offers a highly optimized C++ code for HierNMF2 and DC-NMF (Divide-and-Conquer NMF) that computes overlapping and non-hierarchical topics from HierNMF2. The substantial computational experiments show that SmallK offers one of the fastest and most accurate results for topic discovery and clustering when compared to other existing open-source software.

 

In addition, a variant of NMF called SymNMF was developed for graph clustering and community detection. By merging the SymNMF for graph clustering and the standard NMF for  topic discovery, a method called JointNMF was designed. JointNMF is a powerful method that can discover communities utilizing not only the connection structure information as in a social network but also the content information. For example, when JointNMF is applied to Twitter, one can discover the community structure in the data by utilizing both connection structure and the content of tweets. As multiple data features are used, the results are more accurate than those obtained by using only connection or only text data.  Similarly, when one needs to cluster research papers or patents, most existing methods rely only on the content of the documents but using JointNMF, the data set can be clustered more accurately utilizing both content and network information such as citations or co-author network information.

 

The above variants of NMF have also been applied to discovery of specific targeted topics, event detection, and anomaly detection in document as well as network data sets.
